description: Rada Miskovic, after confiding in a trusted colleague, decides to withhold state media support for the Council's BCI reform vote. Instead, she quietly directs her team to divert resources and publish practical guides on local organizing and energy/resource sharing across affected neighborhoods.

As the city suffers from a severe heatwave and BCI system outages, neighborhood groups increasingly bypass compliance checkpoints. Rada's guides circulate widely, empowering residents to meet urgent needs independently of citywide scoring.

Grassroots collectives become primary sources of aid, distributing power, food, and water, as BCI-regulated services fail in lower-score districts. Residents across score tiers join cooperative efforts, fostering broader solidarity.

The effectiveness and growing reach of these local assemblies draw attention from parts of the media and even high-score citizens. Debates over the future of city governance expand as collective action spreads beyond initial neighborhoods.

Council debates escalate: Innovators acknowledge grassroots successes and suggest reevaluating BCI authority, while Directorate loyalists demand crackdowns. Attempts at forceful intervention are met with organized civilian resistance, revealing the system's declining control.
